Not sure if this question has been asked before, so happy to read through any relevant resources if I'm pointed in the right direction :slightly_smiling_face:

Q: Do any agencies here have experience working with industry experts to produce thought leadership content? A bit of context: one of our latest clients is a law firm that's well known for cracking "impossible" cases. They're basically the veterans that other lawyers look to / refer tough cases to. But their digital presence is nonexistent, so they approached us to do up a website and content strategy to expand their reach beyond word-of-mouth referrals.

Typically our approach has been to write the content for our clients in-house. With our level of analytical research + detail + SEO expertise, we've seen great results with that so far. However, with more and more industry experts coming to us, there's an increasing depth of knowledge required -- a depth that I don't feel we're equipped to deliver on. (I've never practiced law or medicine, after all...) With Google also moving towards the E.A.T. algo, this area has become vital for us to explore.

I'm wondering if it's viable to work closely with those industry experts to help them produce content -- as in, we'd advise on SEO, UX, funnels, and topics, but they'd be the ones actually writing the content. We'd then help to edit + design + publish to make sure all the technical SEO elements are in place.

The tricky part is that a lot of industry experts in our local scene find writing challenging (either they think they're terrible writers or they can't find the time to write), so I'm wondering how to make the process smoother for them.

text:
> The tricky part is that a lot of industry experts in our local scene find writing challenging (either they think they’re terrible writers or they can’t find the time to write), so I’m wondering how to make the process smoother for them.
My process is to first explain what I’m looking for from a content strategy pov. Then I get the client to brainstorm ideas and explain how that idea matches what I’m looking for. We decide which ideas are worth pursuing and then I get them to write an outline first since that generally helps people write better/faster. I let them write the first draft and then I make edits.

Remind them that editing is part of your job so if their writing is less than perfect, it’s okay. The more you do it, the easier it gets, and your client will feel more comfortable doing it.

text: A good way that I have gotten around this is interview the person (10-15 minutes), have it structured with questions that are SEO-driven, and record the interview. You can then transcribe it using a tool like <http://rev.com|rev.com> and then you don’t have to write, you just have to edit
